Award.AwardTitle: CSR: IEEE PerCom 2010 Student Travel Support

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project provides support for US students to attend the 8th IEEE International Conference on Pervasive Computing and Communications
(PerCom 2010), which will be held in Mannheim, Germany between March 29th, 2010 and April 2nd, 2010. IEEE PerCom is the premier technical forum in the rapidly emerging and important area of pervasive computing and networking. Graduate student participation in a key conference like IEEE PerCom is extremely important part of graduate education and would help motivate students to engage in research in a variety of pervasive computing aspects. The European venue for the conference will further help US students to interact with European researchers. The grant primarily supports students who will not be able to a attend the conference otherwise.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This travel grant received from the NSF was used to support US based students to attend the IEEE International Conference on Pervasive Computing and Communications (PerCom 2010) held in Mannheim, Germany during March 29-April 02,  2010. This is a high quality conference sponsored by IEEE Computer Society's Technical Committee on Computer Communications (TCCC) and Technical Committee on Distributed Computing (TCDP).  Pervasive computing and communications is an advancing area of research and development that has become very prominent due to the ubiquitous presence of devices (e.g. cellphones) sensors and RFIDs. It is critical to expose our students to current research issues and challenges.  The NSF funded travel grant achieved this objective.

Fourteen students were selected, from a pool of applications. The conference included technical presentations, keynotes, panels, workshops and demonstrations.  The students had the opportunity to listen to presentations on high quality research, interact with researchers during the posters and demonstrations, and participate in workshops and panels. They also had several opportunities to meet with some of the leading researchers from both academia and industry,  working  in the areas of pervasive computing and communications. All students reported that they benefitted immensely from their experience at the conference.

The supported students included two women, 2 minority students and one speech impaired person.
